entry.title: FASA Star Trek Starship Combat Simulator Introduction
entry.content:
The FASA Star Trek Starship Tactical Combat Simulator is a tabletop role-playing game supplement released in the mid-1980s by FASA (Fantasy Amateur Simulations Association), which held the license to produce Star Trek gaming products at that time. Here's a summary:

  • Gameplay: This game is designed for players to engage in space combat scenarios within the Star Trek universe. It focuses on tactical combat between starships, with rules for movement, combat, and damage. Players can control various Starfleet vessels or ships from different alien races like the Klingons, Romulans, or the Federation's own ships.
  • Components: The game includes several components like ship cards or sheets detailing the stats of different starships, counters or miniatures for representing ships on a game board or map, and dice for resolving combat and other random events. There are also extensive tables for ship movement, weapon ranges, damage, and repair.
  • Rules System: The combat system uses a hexagonal grid for movement and positioning, simulating the three-dimensional aspect of space battles. Players decide their ship's movements, power allocation to systems (like shields, weapons, and engines), and engage in combat rounds where actions like firing phasers or photon torpedoes are resolved.
  • Scenarios: The game comes with pre-designed scenarios or allows players to create their own, setting up different tactical situations or fleet engagements. Scenarios can range from small skirmishes to large fleet actions, each with specific objectives like protecting a convoy or capturing an enemy ship.
  • Role-Playing Elements: While primarily tactical, it can be integrated with FASA's broader Star Trek RPG to include role-playing elements where players might take on roles like captain, tactical officer, or engineer, making strategic decisions beyond just combat.
  • Detail and Complexity: The simulator is known for its detailed rules reflecting the complexities of Star Trek technology and combat scenarios. This includes managing energy distribution, dealing with hull and system damage, and the strategic use of different ship capabilities like cloaking devices or tractor beams.
  • Compatibility: It was meant to be used with the broader Star Trek: The Role-Playing Game by FASA, allowing characters from the RPG to command ships in these tactical scenarios.

This game appeals to fans of Star Trek who enjoy the strategic and tactical aspects of starship combat, offering a detailed and somewhat complex system to simulate the feel of battles seen in the Star Trek series and films. However, the game's depth might require some learning curve for new players.

entry.title: Introduction to Second Edition
entry.content:
Published in 1990

Full Thrust Second Edition is a tabletop miniature wargame by Ground Zero Games that simulates space combat in a sci-fi setting. Here's a summary:

  • Gameplay: Players command fleets of starships, engaging in tactical space battles. The game uses a turn-based system where players manage movement, combat, and ship systems. It's known for its fast-paced and straightforward mechanics, making it accessible yet tactical.
  • Components: The game includes ship templates or counters, dice (six-sided), and often custom miniatures or models representing various spacecraft. Players can use any miniatures, but the game provides stats for ships from different factions or designs.
  • Rules System:
    • Movement: Ships move with pre-plotted free-form movement, with thrust managed by "thrust points" representing engine power.
    • Combat: Weapons like lasers, missiles, and particle beams have different ranges and effects. Combat resolution involves dice rolls, typically comparing the attack roll against a target number based on range, weapon, and defensive capabilities.
    • Damage: Ships have areas or systems (like engines, weapons, shields) that can be damaged or destroyed, affecting performance. Damage allocation can be random or determined by player choice for strategic depth.
  • Ship Design: One of the hallmarks of Full Thrust is its ship design system. Players can design their own ships using a points system, balancing speed, armor, firepower, and other attributes like ECM (Electronic Counter Measures) or fighters.
  • Scenarios and Campaigns: While the core game provides scenarios for immediate play, it's flexible for players to create their own or engage in campaigns where fleet composition and ship status persist between games, adding a strategic layer to fleet management.
  • Setting: The game doesn't enforce a specific universe, allowing for generic sci-fi or adaptation to existing franchises or custom settings. However, it has its own background with factions like the NAC (New Anglian Confederation) or the ESU (Earth Systems Union).
  • Editions: The Second Edition refined the rules from the first, improving clarity, balancing, and adding options. Subsequent expansions and rule clarifications have been published, but the Second Edition remains a popular choice for its balance of simplicity and depth.
  • Community: Full Thrust has a dedicated following, with fans often creating additional rules, ships, and scenarios. There's a significant amount of homebrew content available, expanding the game's scope and replayability.

Full Thrust is celebrated for its blend of accessibility and tactical gameplay, making it a go-to for both new gamers interested in space combat and veterans looking for a system with depth in fleet engagements.
